sections.title: Absorption
sections.content: When taken orally, most BZD show rapid and complete absorption from GI tract

sections.title: Distribution
sections.content: -Increase lipophilicity = Increase rate of CNS distribution. -Cross BBB by passive diffusion.

sections.title: Metabolism
sections.content: -Do NOT induce metabolism of other drugs. -Liver metabolized to active compounds (except lorazepam)

sections.title: Excretion
sections.content: By kidneys

sections.title: Duration of Action
sections.content: [Short Acting]: 1.5-5 hours, Not converted into active intermediates. [Intermediate Acting]: 8-20 hours. [Long Acting]: 30-60 hours, Converted into active intermediates.

sections.title: Mechanism of Action
sections.content: -Potentiates GABA by binding to allosteric site on receptor. Increase the frequency of Cl- channel opening. -Enhancement of GABA activity slows nerve impulses throughout the body, GABA produces calming effect in the brain.

sections.title: Pharmacological Action
sections.content: -Sedation (decrease latency and REM). -Reduction in muscle tone. -Tolerance develops after 1-2 weeks of use. -Reduction in anxiety.

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Drowsiness, Fatigue, Amnesia, Ataxia

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: Anti-Epileptic (diazepam, lorazepam), Insomnia (temazepam, triazolam), Anti-anxiety (diazepam, lorazepam), Muscle spasms (diazepam), Anesthesia (diazepam, lorazepam, midazolam). *Duration of Action determines therapeutic use.

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: -Duration of action and elimination half life are NOT the same. -BZD increase frequency of Cl- channel opening. -GABA must be present for BZD to have effect. -Flumazenil = BZD receptor antagonist for treatment of acute overdose.

sections.title: Absorption
sections.content: IV and Oral

sections.title: Distribution
sections.content: Increases lipid solubility = quicker entry into CNS. Barbiturates redistribute from brain to muscles and fat tissue.

sections.title: Metabolism
sections.content: Metabolized in the liver

sections.title: Excretion
sections.content: Excreted in urine by kidney

sections.title: MOA Explanation
sections.content: Prolong GABA activity. Increase duration of Cl- channel opening. Also blocks the AMPA- receptor which is sensitive to glutamate, the excitatory transmitter. Blocking this action increases the duration of receptor response to GABA and extends the depressed condition of the cell.

sections.title: Pharmacological Action
sections.content: [CNS Depression]: Sedation at low doses. Hypnosis followed by anesthesia at high doses. [Respiratory Depression]: Suppress hypoxic and chemoreceptor response to C02 -> Can lead to death.

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Alcohol like symptoms: Impaired motor control (ataxia), dizziness, slower breathing and heart rate. Enzyme induction (CYP450). Potential for addiction.

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: NOT used as sedative or hypnotic. Anesthetic: Ultra short acting (thiopental). Anti-seizure: Long acting (phenobarbital).

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: Physical dependence, Severe withdrawal symptoms, low toxicity threshold, tolerance develops.

sections.title: Decrease Excitatory Activity

sections.content: distinguishes antidepressant and antihistamine activity (derived from diphenhydramine)

sections.content: enhances SERT selectivity

sections.title: Explanation
sections.content: Blocks Serotonin Transporter (SERT) on pre-synaptic neuron resulting in increased serotonin in the synapse which is available to bind to post synaptic serotonin receptors.

sections.title: Acute SRI Use
sections.content: 1. Drug blocks 5-HT re-update (SERT) 2. Auto receptor (5-HT1A) activity decreases 3. 5-HT release decreases

sections.title: Chronic SRI Use
sections.content: 1. Auto receptor (5-HT1A) function is lost 2. 5-HT release returns to normal 3. Now serotonin in synapse is greatly increased

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Nausea & GI symptoms, Sexual effects (decreased libido & sexual dysfunction), Mild restlessness, Mild headaches, Mild Insomnia

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: Depression, OCD, panic disorder, anxiety

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: SRIs compete with metabolism of other drugs, Never use in combo with MAOIs (MAOIs inhibit breakdown of SRIs and could lead to overdose of serotonin in the brain)

Compound 2 is a tertiary amine TCA, which acts as a SNRI and would be helpful, but leads to adverse effects such as sedation and hypotension so not recommended in elderly. Compound 3 (venlafaxine) is best choice as it is SNRI, with few adverse effects.

sections.title: SAR Explained
sections.content: [Linker of 3 carbons]: between tricyclic ring system and basic nitrogen. Branching from linker decreases binding affinity for SERT and NET. Unsaturation of linker is tolerated. [R→ CH3]: tertiary amine imparts selectivity for SERT. [R’→ Cl or CN (EWG)]: enhances binding affinity for SERT. [Y→ can be C or N]. [Conformationally rigid [6.7.6]-fused ring system]: 7 membered ring in the middle is not coplanar; results in twisted shape

sections.title: Monoamine Theory
sections.content: Deficiency of 5-HT and NE transmission in the CNS

sections.title: Neurotrophic Theory
sections.content: Decrease of Brain Derived Neurotophic Factor (BDNF) resulting in reduced neuroplasticity, decreased number of spines and thus, decreased neurotransmission.

sections.title: Low dopamine

learnItems.explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 3) Prevents conversion of L-Ala→ D-Ala and the joining of D-Ala & D-Ala.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: GT is diagnosed with C. difficile. Which oral antibiotic would be best to treat his infection?
learnItems.explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) is not orally absorbed, so it will stay in the gut to treat the infection in the large intestine

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: SM is diagnosed with a UTI infection. Which compound would be best to treat his infection and has few side effects?
learnItems.explanation: Fosfomycin (Compound 2) is indicated for urinary tract infections, and is especially active against E. Coli

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: GT has a history of psychosis. Which antibiotic below is best avoided in this patient?
learnItems.explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 1) acts as a partial agonist at the NMDA receptor can result in dose-dependent neurologic and psychiatric disturbances.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: BK has kidney dysfunction. Which 2 antibiotics below have side effects that would be harmful to this patient?
learnItems.explanation: Bacitracin (Compound 1) and vancomycin (Compound 3) can both result in nephrotoxicity.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: AM’s bacterial infection is not responding to treatment. The bacteria in her body have become resistant to the antibiotic by producing D-Ala-D-Lac. Which of the antibiotics was she taking?
learnItems.explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) normally binds to D-Ala-D-Ala of the pentapeptide tail, but with this change to D-Ala-D-Lac, it can no longer bind.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: Any change will lower activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 4
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfur is usual, but not essential

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: No substitutions allowed; cis stereochemistry with hydrogens at position 5 & 6 is essential

compoundHotspots.name: R Group
compoundHotspots.text: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more B-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carbonyl

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: R2 Group: Non-metabolized group: increases oral activity & acid stability. MTT group: extended spectrum, longer-half life, higher potency. Pyrimidine ring (positive charge): forms a zwitterion & increases solubility. 1,3 thiazole ring: Anti-MRSA activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 6

Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria. Oxime: increases B-lactamase resistance.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: R3 group: Addition of OCH3 (7-alpha-methoxy) increases B-lactamase resistance

compoundHotspots.name: Position 8

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -β-lactam ring (tetracyclic amide) is essential. -Any modification to β-lactam ring results in inactivation

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Irreversible, 'suicide' inhibitor of many (but not all) bacterial β-lactamases. Covalently bind to serine residue of active site of β-lactamases

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: No antimicrobial activity. Used in combination with penicillins to increase spectrum of activity

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: - Single β-lactam ring. -A methyl group can be placed at R2 for β-lactamase stability. -R1 can be changed to an extent to improve spectrum and activity. -SO3 group facilitates ring opening. -Methoxy group improves β-lactamase stability but decreases ring stability

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Interferes with bactericidal cell wall synthesis by binding to and inactivating penicillin-binding-proteins. This binding causes the formation of elongation or bacterial filamentation resulting in cell lysis and cell death. Bactericidal

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Resistance to aztreonam is primarily through hydrolysis by beta-lactamase, alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), and decreased permeability.

sections.title: Spectrum & Toxicities
sections.content: Spectrum: Gram negative. Toxicities: Rash, diarrhea

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Unsaturated 5-membered ring connected to the β-lactam ring. -β-lactam ring and COOH are essential for function. -R1 and R2 are variable regions that can alter spectrum, susceptibility to lactamases and stability.

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Cause rapid bacterial cell death by covalently binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) involved in the biosynthesis of mucopeptides in bacterial cell walls.  Bactericidal effects result through inhibition of cellular growth and division and the loss of cell wall integrity, eventually causing cell wall lysis. The primary target is PBP-2.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Modified porins 2. Efflux pumps 3. Synthesis of inactivating enzymes (very uncommon)

sections.title: Spectrum & Toxicities
sections.content: Spectrum: Broadest spectrum (gram positive and negative). Toxicities: GI, Renal insufficiency, Hepatic insufficiency, Anemia

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: β-lactam ring & fused bicyclic system: creates a strained system. -Position 1: must be a nitrogen. -Position 2: must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site. -Position 3: any change will lower activity. Position 4: sulfur is usual, but not essential. Position 5: no substitutions allowed; cis stereochemistry with hydrogens at position 5 & 6 is essential. [R Group]: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more β-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria. Position 7: must be a carbonyl

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Inhibits cell peptidoglycan synthesis – specifically crosslinking of peptidoglycan strands. Bactericidal

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Synthesis of inactivating enzymes ->  β-lactamases  (less common in cephalosporin’s) 2. Mutations to PBP (decreases affinity of drug to target). 3. Alternation of porins (decrease ability of drug to reach site of action in bacteria).

sections.title: Spectrum, Target, Type, & Toxicities
sections.content: [Spectrum]: Early penicillin’s gram positive only, but as a class they are broad spectrum. [Target]: Penicillin Binding Proteins (PBPs). [Inhibitor Type]: Irreversible covalent inhibitor/ suicide inhibitor – substrate mimic. [Toxicities]:Immune response (low incidence), nephrotoxicity, pseudomonas colitis, seizures.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: [β-lactam ring & fused bicyclic system]: creates a strained system (but less strain than the penicillins, so less reactive). [Position 1]: must be a nitrogen. [Position 2]: must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site. [Position 3]: R2 group: -Non-metabolized group: increases oral activity & acid stability. MTT group: extended spectrum, longer-half life, higher potency. -Pyrimidine ring (positive charge): forms a zwitterion & increases solubility. -1,3 thiazole ring: Anti-MRSA activity. [Position 5]: sulfur is usual, but not essential. [Position 6]: no substitutions allowed. [Position 7]: R3 group-addition of OCH3 (7-alpha-methoxy) increases β-lactamase resistance. [R1 group]: -EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. -Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more β-lactamase resistant. -Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria. -Oxime: increases β-lactamase resistance. [Position 8]: must be a carbonyl.

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Inhibits cell peptidoglycan synthesis – specifically crosslinking of peptidoglycan strands. Bactericidal

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Synthesis of inactivating enzymes ->  β-lactamases  (less common in cephalosporin’s) 2. Mutations to PBP (decreases affinity of drug to target). 3. Alternation of porins (decrease ability of drug to reach site of action in bacteria).

sections.title: Spectrum, Target, Type, & Toxicities
sections.content: [Spectrum]: Dependent on generation, some have very broad spectrum – even effective against organisms that produce β-lactamases. [Target]: Penicillin Binding Proteins (PBPs). [Inhibitor Type]: Irreversible covalent inhibitor – suicide inhibitors. [Toxicities]: Immune response (cross reactivity with other β-lactams) – otherwise low, nephrotoxicity, pseudomonas colitis, seizures. A-Typical side effects due to MTT group: Hypothrombocytopenia, Disulfiram-like effect

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: Essential components: [Benzene ring]. [Un-substituted amine para to sulfonamide]. [Sulfonamide para to amine]: -Sulfonamide must be un-ionized to cross bacterial cell membrane. -Sulfonamide must be ionized to interact with DHPS active site. -Disubstitution of sulfonamide abolishes activity (acidic hydrogen required). -Mono-substituted sulfonamide may increase activity (EWG & heterocycles favorable)

sections.title: Target
sections.content: Dihydropteroate Synthase(DHPS)

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: PABA mimic that competitively inhibits the synthesis of dihydrofolic acid from PABA. Bacteriostatic.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Decreased drug uptake (most common). 2. Overexpression of DHPS 3. Increase PABA in bacteria 4. Decrease affinity for sulfonamide by DHPS

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Broad Spectrum but use as monotherapy is rare

sections.title: Toxicity
sections.content: Nephrotoxicity; Crystalluria, Rash, Photosensitivity, Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Removal of primary amine results in complete inactivity. -Removal of one or more methoxy groups on trimethoprim results in loss of activity to varying degrees.

sections.title: Target
sections.content: Dihydrofolate Reductase (DHFR)

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Inhibits a step of the recycling of the folate cofactor (dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate) for purine and thymidine biosynthesis. Binds with ~300x more affinity to bacteria vs. human DHFR. Bacteriostatic

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Overexpression of DHFR. 2. Decrease affinity for sulfonamide due to mutated enzyme.

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Broad Spectrum. Used in synergy with sulfonamides because of resistance.

sections.title: Toxicity
sections.content: Hypersensitivity rash, Hyperkalemia, Hematologic effects

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: (Ciprofloxacin, Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin)

sections.title: Mechanism of Action & Target
sections.content: MOA: Irreversibly inhibits topoisomerase (DNA gyrase) enzymes, which inhibits relaxation of supercoiled DNA and promotes breakage of double stranded DNA. Bactericidal. Target: Topoisomerase II (DNA Gyrase)

sections.title: Mechanism of Resistance
sections.content: 1. Mutation to the quinolone-resistance determining region (QRDR) of gyrase that affects the binding of fluoroquinolones. 2. Active drug efflux. 3. Decrease drug uptake (reduced permeability)

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Broad spectrum (increases with increasing generation)

sections.title: Toxicities/DDI’s
sections.content: Tendon rupture, QT prolongation, Phototoxicity. Rashes, Peripheral neuropathy. DDI: Chelation with cations, synergistic inhibition of GABA receptor with NSAIDs

sections.title: Ring 3
sections.content: The amine can be methylated or changed to a hydroxyl group, but its removal will abolish activity.

sections.title: Polycationic at physiological pH
sections.content: Poor oral absorption

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: -Binds irreversibly to the 30S ribosomal subunit and changes to the “A” site. -Enters cell by binding negatively charged phospholipids and entering via electron transport linked system -> method can be antagonized by divalent cations. Bactericidal. Target: 30S

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Decreased permeation of aminoglycosides (loss of porin). 2. Bacteria produce enzymes that acetylate or phosphorylate aminoglycosides’ hydroxyl groups to make aminoglycoside inactive. 3. Ribosomal mutations.

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Very broad spectrum, but better against G-. Used mainly against G- bacilli AEROBES.

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: Nephrotoxicity, Ototoxicity, Neuromuscular blockade (muscular paralysis)

sections.title: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12, & 12a
sections.content: Any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration. Resonance between position 10 and 11 needed for activity.

sections.title: Position 2
sections.content: Any changes leads to decreased activity, even substitution to the amide

sections.title: Position 4
sections.content: Amine in the α-position is essential, but monosubstitution is also active

sections.title: Position 5
sections.content: R4 can be a hydroxyl, keto group or a hydrogen, and all are active

sections.title: Position 6
sections.content: Both substitutions (R2 and R3) are not necessary

sections.title: Position 7
sections.content: Cl, F, Br, NO2 and a tertiary amine are all active

sections.title: Position 8
sections.content: Any electron withdrawing or donating group is still active

sections.title: Position 9
sections.content: bulky substitution decreases resistance

sections.title: Warhead
sections.content: Resonance between 11 and 12

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Binds reversibly to 30S ribosomal subunit at the A site, preventing attachment of tRNA – leading to termination of translation. Bacteriostatic. Target: 30S

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Develops efflux pumps. 2. Genes for tet-resistance transmitted by plasmids. 3. Enzymatic modification of antibiotic preventing binding to 30S.

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Broad spectrum: G+, G-, aerobic and anaerobic

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: Phototoxicity, Inhibition of bone growth, nephrotoxic, hepatotoxic , stains teeth. DDI: chelation with cations (dairy products, antacids, supplements)

learnItems.question: Will the following change increase or decrease acid stability?
learnItems.explanation: 15 member ring (with no ketone) increases acid stability and permits accumulation of azithromycin in the cell.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Activity Change
learnItems.question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
learnItems.explanation: Cl increases lipophilicity and has better oral absorption.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which compound is less susceptible to bacteria resistance?
learnItems.explanation: Telithromycin (Compound 1) because the addition of 3-keto group and carbamate side chain.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of the following is NOT bacteriostatic?
learnItems.explanation: Gentamicin (Compound 1) because Aminoglycosides are bactericidal.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Choose the Correct Answer
learnItems.question: Gray Baby Syndrome results from inability to produce which metabolite?
learnItems.explanation: No explanation provided.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: Lucille Mangonzy is experiencing diarrhea after taking her antibiotic, which compound did she most likely take?
learnItems.explanation: Clindamycin (Compound 3) has highest incidence of pseudomembranous colitis.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: Which compound is less susceptible to bacteria resistance?
learnItems.explanation: Chloramphenicol (Compound 1) has a major toxicity of aplastic anemia.

testItems.question: Macrolides have many DDI’s with other drugs such as _______ .
_______ has evidence for liver transplant.
The macrolide ________ is a prodrug activated by hydrolysis.
Synercid, a combination including quinupristin and dalfopristin, can only be administered with _______.
High levels of chloramphenicol may cause fatal neonatal toxicity and _______ .
A side effect of Streptogramin is _______ .
Azithromycin has a caution for patients as risk of _______ .
_______ has the least potential for Cyp450 inhibition.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Large lactone ring (12, 14, or 16 membered ring). -Contain one or two sugars usually desosamine and/or cladinose. -Connection via ester bond. -Synthetic modifications made on the sugar and the 6 and 12-OH.

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Inhibit elongation, promote dissociation of peptidyl t-RNA before completion of peptide synthesis by blocking exit tunnel. Reversible binding. Bacteriostatic.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Methylation A2058 by ermC

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: 100x more affinity for gram positive vs gram negative

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: QT prolongation, hepatitis, p450 inhibitor (carbamazepines, benzodiazepines, warfarin, theophylline, prednisone, cyclosporins, statins)

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Replacement of the L-cladinose sugar of erythromycin A with a 3-keto functional group: Restores activity against bacteria with inducible resistance mediated by Erm, and enhances activity against streptococci with Mef-mediated macrolide efflux. -Addition of a carbamate side chain: Promotes activity against both erythromycin-sensitive and erythromycin-resistant bacteria by introducing an interaction with domain II of the 23S rRNA.

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Inhibit elongation, promote dissociation of peptidyl t-RNA before completion of peptide synthesis by blocking exit tunnel. Reversible binding. Increased affinity for ribosome (2 binding sites for 23 rRNA). Bacteriostatic

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Methylation A2058 by ermC

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Good gram positive

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: QT prolongation, hepatitis, p450 inhibitor (carbamazepines, benzodiazepines, warfarin, theophylline, prednisone, cyclosporins, statins)

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Eight carbon sugar. -Amide bond.

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Reversibly binds to the 23S portion of 50S, block translocation of tRNA from A site to P site, blocks elongation. Bacteriostatic.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Target-site modification by methylation  of the 23S ribosomal target site, encoded by the erm(B) gene and prevents the binding of the antibiotic to its ribosomal target

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: anaerobic gram positive and negative

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: GI, rashes, pseudomembranous colitis

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Dalfopristin: irreversibly binds to 23S portion of the 50S (blocks the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA). Quinupristin: irreversibly binds to a nearby site on the 50S (inhibits peptide bond formation and elongation). Synergism. Conformational change of the ribosome and enhance the binding of quinupristin. Bactericidal together. Bacteriostatic alone. Target: 23S (D), 50S (Q); P site.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: (2) target-site modification by methylation  of the 23S ribosomal target site, encoded by the erm(B) gene and prevents the binding of the antibiotic to its ribosomal target. (3) through efflux of the antibiotic. (4) Enzymatic inactivation of drug.

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Gram positive. (Too big to enter gram negative).

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: Muscle/joint pain, infusion related events (pain/thrombophlebitis). Cyp3A4 inhibitor so DDIs, myalgia and arthralgia

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Nitro group: can be replaced with other EWG, but activity decreases. -Aromatic ring: essential for activity. -Chlorines: can be removed or replaced with other halogens, but activity decreases. -R, R stereoisomer: essential for activity.

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Reversibly Inhibits peptidyl transferase reaction (blocks peptide elongation), competes for macrolide and clindamycin binding. Bacteriostatic (bacteriocidal to influenzae).

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Plasmid-encoded acetyltransferase that inactivates drug. 2. Chloramphenicol aetyltransferase (CAT).

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Broad (gram positive, gram negative, anaerobes and atypicals)

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: Significant toxicity, so rarely used. Hemolytic anemia (GSH reasoning), mammalian mitochondrial protein synthesis can be inhibited (erythrolpoietic cells highly sensitive)

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: -Oxazolidinone ring

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: Binds to alt. site on 50S from MLS drugs to prevent initiation complex formation.‘cidal for streptococci, ‘static for staphylococci and enterococci.

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Mutations on 23S rRNA binding site

sections.title: Indication/Spectrum
sections.content: Gram positive only (similar to vanco)

sections.title: Toxicity/DDI
sections.content: MAO inhibitors so not with SSRIs, bone marrow suppression, mitochondrial toxicity
